author: sky.cactus
content:
1. If the threat is credible it is quite unlikely we'll need to actually fork.
2. If the threat isn't credible, then PoS is game theoretically broken.
So essentially we are either in a scenario where we cannot fork, in which case everything is broken and it would be better to find out sooner rather than later, or we are in a scenario where we can fork in which case we don't really need to worry too much about it because the ability to do it makes it so it likely won't be necessary.  The above is all regardless of whether withdraws are implemented now or in a year.

author: sky.cactus
content: While I agree with you that allowing movement of funds sooner rather than later is a "softer touch" solution than a fork, that doesn't change the calculus for whether or not the fork is credible, which is what *really* matters here.

author: Deleted User
content: "If the threat isn't credible, then PoS is game theoretically broken."  Isn't this similar to PoW?  if 51% of hashrate censors, community needs to coordinate on social hash algo fork

author: sky.cactus
content: No, under Proof of Stake the threat isn't credible because you have to burn *all* hashpower (it isn't targeted) and the attacker may be able to re-use/re-sell/re-purpose their hardware (thus they aren't actually harmed).

author: sky.cactus
content: Bitcoin is in a slightly better position due to being ASICs, but it still isn't great because you have to burn everyone (not only the attacker).

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, when you burn all of that hardware down under PoW you are just burning it.  Under PoS, arguably the stake gets "redistributed" to holders (by way of monetary supply decrease), which makes it a nicer pill to swallow for users.

author: pietjepuk
content:
In a world where everything is black and white, sure. We don't live in such a world though. A fork taking away funds
1) has a very high barrier in forming consensus among devs, when is it ok, when isn't it. Not building on top of a certain block, not attesting to it, not aggregating messages for it (sneaky) not propagating messages or txs, what shade of gray is black here?
2) unsure who it is you're punishing. The offending party, or the (mostly also users) that have delegated their money to earn interest on it.

Instead of figuring out what undesirable/offending behavior is deterred by the threat of a fork, I'd say it's much healthier for the system at large to have less severe, low-barrier, measures. And withdrawals (also a threat of losing money for service providers for bad behavior) also matches the shades of gray of offending behavior. Outrageous behavior (with the threat of a fork) could lead to lots of users withdrawing such that the fork is not necessary. Less bad behavior could lead to at least some people withdrawing (=loss of income for staking provider).

I'm not saying that centralized staking providers is something we want to have, but reality is that we do and lots of people use them (for various reasons, not having 32 ETH or wanting the liquidity). And unless those centralizing forces are non-existent, I _do_ symphatize with them (to some extent, like not burning their money without giving them an out).

author: sky.cactus
content: The threat of a fork is the final backstop.  While there are other things that can be done to avoid reaching the final backstop, the final backstop **MUST** work for Ethereum to be secure.  Ethereum is not secure with the rest of the measures alone.  My argument here is that while those measures are nice, if you don't believe the fork will actually work then it means you don't believe that Ethereum's security protocol works.  If that is the case, we should address that rather than talking about the secondary measures that help us try to cover up the fact that the final backstop is broken.

author: sky.cactus
content: At best, those secondary measures (like staking liquidity) help buy time until the final backstop is needed, but we still need the final backstop to be functional and credibly so.

author: sky.cactus
content: If I thought it were possible, I would recommend that we intentionally exercise the final backstop somehow to make it very clear just how credible it is.

Over the years, there has been a huge amount of proposal to improve or radically alter the EVM, but backwards compatibility issues and complexity made it impossible. We now have proposals such as AES, Verkle tries, account abstraction which would alter even more the design of basic components of Ethereum and they also suffer from maintaining backwards compatibility. Since now Ethereum has a clear division of roles in the consensus and execution layer, I wonder if it wouldn't make sense to start thinking about introducing a second, completely novel execution layer, with all the things we want? This would allow Execution Layer 1 client to go in maintenance mode /R&D to move the layer 1 to weak statelessness. We would lose composability across the 2 execution layers but it might make sense considering that we would shift to an entirely new address format.
